entry.title: Workshops, Fires, New computer, and a Datathon!
entry.summary:
Fires

It‚Äôs been a terrible start of the year for Australia. I‚Äôve been following the news over on The Guardian.

As a result, we‚Äôve decided to donate 50% of our profits (i.e.¬†just less the venue costs and teaching time), from our two workshops in Feb. Hopefully this will be a few thousand dollars.

If you want to do more, my friend Milly noted in a nice thread you can also remove your money from banks and superannuation firms that fund fossil fuel. Bank Australia has been my choice. Finally, Gala and I have also gone through our house and found a bunch of things to give away.

Here‚Äôs some good links if you‚Äôre looking for places to donate:

  • GiveNow - How Can I Donate To Help With The Bushfies?
  • The Guardian - Do your homework, give cash and avoid scams: How to donate to Australia‚Äôs bushfire crisis

So, here we go, the books that I finished this year, in no particular order.

We are in the middle of gatherings, celebrations and reflections.

Several things happened during the year and we want to share them with you:

entry.title: Broadside 2019 Debrief
entry.summary:
Our haul of books from the Broadside book shop!

Gala and I went to the Broadside festival, put on by the Wheeler Centre, last weekend. You can find people tweeting about it here. You can also find a cool image review by the Wheeler Centre themselves.

The festival was billed as ‚ÄúAn unapologetically feminist agenda‚Äù; and it really delivered. Not only was it full of feminist views, those views were being shared by a quite diverse set of people.

entry.title: Braneshop — "A Living Business" - Part 3 of 3
entry.summary:
Rough grouping of Patterns for Braneshop.

  • Part 1 of 3 - Inspiration
  • Part 2 of 3 - The Idea: A Living Business
  • Part 3 of 3 - Patterns for Braneshop (this page)

In the final installment of this series, we look at a few of the ‚Äúpatterns‚Äù that will help us understand where we‚Äôre at as a business.

The main point here will be to list those patterns ‚Äî the patterns of behaviour, attitudes, business processes ‚Äî that we‚Äôd like to have at Braneshop.

The patterns should be measurable insofar as we ourselves will need to ask ourselves how well we‚Äôre doing when measuring ourselves on them. And we won‚Äôt be doing perfectly on each of them, and over the years we can expect our success across any given one to fluctuate. But that‚Äôs okay. The process is what is important.

entry.title: AI For Leadership Workshop - Breakdown
entry.summary:
Watch on Vimeo - Snapshot of the attendees over the day.


One of the teams, at the first AI For Leadership workshop, working through one of the exercises.

Last month we had our first AI for Leadership workshop. In this post we take a look at what we covered, and discuss a few of the things we learned.

entry.title: Introducing the CPPN Playground!
entry.summary:
The main interface of the CPPN playground; reproducing a cool rendering of a black hole.

As we saw in the business card blog post we love ‚ÄúCPPNs‚Äù here.

We wanted to share the fun, so I made a little JavaScript app where you can play around with them. You can access it here: CPPN Playground.

There‚Äôs a few main things you can do:

  1. Look at the cool pictures! And adjust the network to get more.
  2. Train the network to reproduce a specific picture.
  3. Download a big (1000x1000) version of the image!

entry.title: Introduction to Explainable AI - 6th of Nov, 2019
entry.summary:
Join us for an evening of Explainable AI!

Join us on the 6th of November for an Introduction to Explainable AI - Opening the black box!

From talking to people across different businesses for the last few months, we know that there is significant interest in ‚Äúexaplainble‚Äù AI models. The reason is natural: When we deploy these decision-making tools, we need to understand why they make decisions; as this helps us learn if they are doing the ‚Äúright‚Äù thing. And furthermore, it let‚Äôs us improve or adjust our processes.

Our intention is to give you a high-level overview, and cover one or two areas in some detail, so you can get a feel for what‚Äôs involved.

As such, we‚Äôve organised an event to explore the landscape of Explainable AI. In particular, we will:

  • Look at what‚Äôs available,
  • Work out what is involved in applying it,
  • and, Learn where the field is heading!

We‚Äôre bringing together a few people in Melbourne who are doing interesting work in this area!

After attending this event, you should be able to understand:
